TECHNICAL WRITER PORTFOLIO Flight Operations & QRH Standards REVISION: 1.2 DATE: 25 DEC 2025

Prepared for: Flight Operations Documentation Review

Welcome. This portfolio demonstrates the integration of Subject Matter Expertise (SME) with Docs-as-Code methodologies.

As a B737 Pilot with over 3,000 flight hours, I specialize in translating complex manufacturer data (Boeing/Ryanair) into clear, version-controlled technical documentation.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This document outlines the standard procedure for creating, versioning, and publishing Flight Operations documentation using the Docs-as-Code methodology.

docs.title: Tools & Environment
docs.text:
• Authoring: Visual Studio Code (Markdown)
  • Version Control: Git & GitHub
  • Rendering Engine: MkDocs (Material Theme)
  • Distribution: Adobe Acrobat (PDF/A Optimized)

docs.title: 1. Authoring Process
docs.text: All documents are authored in Markdown to ensure a clear separation between content and formatting. This allows for: * Rapid updates during aircraft fleet changes. * Consistency across different Emergency/Normal checklists.

docs.title: 2. Version Control (The Git Flow)
docs.text: To ensure data integrity, every change follows a tracked workflow: 1. Staging: git add . (Preparing updates for the next release). 2. Snapshot: git commit -m "Description of change" (Creating a searchable history). 3. Deployment: git push (Syncing with the master repository).

docs.title: 3. Quality Assurance & Publishing
docs.text:
Before a document is released for EFB (Electronic Flight Bag) use: * Peer Review: Changes are reviewed via GitHub Pull Requests. * Acrobat Optimization: The final HTML/Markdown output is converted to PDF. * Technical Check: Hyperlinks (like the one in the Cabin Altitude QRH) are verified for iPad compatibility.

End of Procedure

docs.title: Rapid Depressurization (RYR)
docs.text: Note: Use of the autopilot is reccomended

docs.title: Memory Items (Rapid Depressurization)
docs.text:
CAPTAIN (PF) FIRST OFFICER (PM) 1. Oxygen Mask - ON, 100% 1. Oxygen Mask - ON, 100% 2. Crew Comms - Establish 2. Crew Comms - Establish 3. Assumes PF Role 3. Assumes PM Role 4. Monitor Pressurization 4. • Pressurization Mode Selector — MAN • Outflow Valve Switch — CLOSE (Hold) • If Pressurization is restored, continue manual operation to maintain proper cabin altiude

If cabin altitude is uncontrollable:

5. 5. Passenger Oxygen Switch - ON 6. 6. Passenger Signs - ON 7. Emergency Descent - Iniate 7. Monitor Descent 8. Announce Emergency Descent 8. Engine Start Switches - CONT 9. Select lower ALT on MCP ALT selector 9. Set 7700 and select TA on the transponder mode selector 10. Select LVL CHG 10. • Contact ATC - Mayday Call • State new HDG • Request QNH • Request descent to 10,000ft MSA 11. Select HDG SEL and turn approximately 45 degrees off existing HDG or track, terrain considerations permitting 11. Turn ON Turnoff and Inboard Landing lights 12. Close thrust levers manually 12. Set QNH 13. Select speed brake to Flight Detent 13. Monitos TCAS and Descent 14. Select MCP SPD to VMO/MMO or limit speed as required 14. Read Deprussurization and Emergency Descent QRH Checklist 15. • Tidy up MCP - ALT • Select QNH and 10,000ft MSA • HDG - Note New HDG • Speed - Ensure VMO/MMO 15. Anticipate turbulence and icing requiments 16. Respond to altitude calls 16. Call every 10,000ft during descent 17. Reduce rate of descent at "TWO TO GO" 17. CALL: "TWO TO GO" 18. Reduce rate of descent at "ONE TO GO" 18. CALL: "ONE TO GO"

WHEN LEVEL

19. When level, set speed appropriate to situation 19. Verify pressurization system and advice the captain when the cabin altitude is below 10,000ft 20. Remove O2 mask when safe and cabin altitude is below 10,000ft.Select Boom at audio control panel 20. Remove O2 mask when safe and cabin altitude is below 10,000ft.Select Boom at audio control panel 21. "NUMBER ONE TO THE FLIGHT DECK" for NITS drills 21. Complete NNC 22. Review fuel requirements and coordinate intensions with ATC 22. 23. Plan for depressurized Flight, Descent, Approach and Landing and any medical requirments 23.

docs.title: Nose Low Recovery
docs.text:
Pilot Flying (PF) Pilot Monitoring (PM) • Recognize and confirm the situation
  • Disconnect autopilot and autothrottle
  • Recover from stall, if required
  • * Roll in shortest direction to wings level (unload and roll if bank angle is more than 90 degrees)
  • Recover to level flight:
  • Apply nose up elevator
  • *Apply nose up trim, if required
  • Adjust thrust and drag as required.
  • Call out attitude, airspeed, and altitude throughout the recovery
  • Verify all required actions have been completed and call out any omissions

docs.title: WARNING: * Excessive use of pitch trim or rudder may aggravate an upset situation or may result in loss of control and/or high structural loads.
docs.text: Source: Derived from Boeing 737 Quick Reference Handbook (QRH) Rev 2014. For training purposes only.

docs.title: Technical Enviroment Setup
docs.text: To maintain a consistent documentation environment, the following commands are used to initialize the Docs-as-Code workspace.

docs.title: Git installed and configured with a GitHub account
VS Code with the "Markdown All in One" extension (recommended)
Install the MkDocs engine
docs.text: pip install mkdocs

docs.title: Create the project structure
docs.text: mkdocs new .

docs.title: Create file hierarchy
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml : The Configuration file

docs/index.md : Thee project landing page

docs/ : The directory containing all source Markdown files

docs.title: Connect the local folder to the remote GitHub repository
docs.text: git remote add origin [https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/portfolio.git](https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/portfolio.git)

docs.title: Set the primary branch to 'main'
docs.text: git branch -M main

docs.title: Perform the initial upload
docs.text: git push -u origin main

docs.title: 3. How to send changes to GitHub
Make your edits in the .md files.
CRITICAL: Update docs/revision-history.md with the new Revision Number and Date.
Run mkdocs serveon terminal to be able to check changes locally.
git add . Stage all changes for Upload.
git commit -m "Brief description of the update" (e.g., "Rev 1.3: Update Winter Ops Checklist)
git push Send your source code to the GitHub repository.
mkdocs gh-deploy Updates the actual live website.
git status Should report "Your branch is up to date" and "nothing to commit, working tree clean".
4. Local Development (Live Preview)
docs.text: mkdocs serve The documentation will be available at http://127.0.0.1:8000
